WHEREAS, Michele Wazny, affectionately known by many as “Maggie,” has dedicated an extraordinary 54 years of service to the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh; and,

 

body

WHEREAS, she began her journey in 1971 as a teenager at the Main Library in Oakland, and for the past 32 years has been a cherished presence at CLP-Mt. Washington, faithfully serving the community; and,

 

WHEREAS, Maggie has demonstrated unwavering dedication to literacy and learning, always staying current with popular and meaningful books to recommend to patrons, and generously offering tours of the CLP-Mt. Washington branch, sharing its rich history with visitors; and,

 

WHEREAS, generations of community members who once visited the library as children now return with their own families, warmly recognizing and reconnecting with Michele, a beloved figure in the neighborhood; and,

 

WHEREAS, a proud resident of Mt. Washington for over 60 years, Maggie shared her life there with her late husband David, a local barber, further embedding her legacy in the fabric of the community; and,

 

NOW, THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the Council of the City of Pittsburgh does hereby recognize Michele Wazny for her dedicated service to the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh and congratulate her upon her retirement; and,

 

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Council of the City of Pittsburgh does hereby declare Thursday, April 3, 2025 to be “Michele Wazny Day” in the City of Pittsburgh.

WHEREAS, the City of Pittsburgh takes great pride in recognizing and celebrating the distinguished legacy and ongoing impact of the Pittsburgh Alumnae Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated, and its members, as they commemorate Delta Days in Pittsburgh 2025; and,

 

body

WHEREAS, Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated was founded on January 13, 1913, by twenty-two visionary collegiate women of African-American descent at Howard University, who committed themselves to the principles of scholarship, sisterhood, and service; and,

 

WHEREAS, for more than a century, Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. has remained at the forefront of social change, guided by its Five-Point Programmatic Thrust, which focuses on Economic Development, Educational Development, International Awareness and Involvement, Physical and Mental Health, and SOCIAL ACTION; and,

 

WHEREAS, the Pittsburgh Alumnae Chapter, chartered in 1927, has for nearly a century demonstrated, through its members, unwavering dedication to advancing the public good, meeting the evolving needs of the community through innovative programming, bold advocacy, and a steadfast commitment to social justice; and,

 

WHEREAS, Delta Days in Pittsburgh serves as an extension of a nationally recognized tradition that engages Delta members in meaningful dialogue with civic leaders at every level of government-including the United States Capitol, state legislatures, and the United Nations-and reflects Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc.’s continued mission to promote leadership, advocacy, and empowerment to effect social change and policies; and,

 

WHEREAS, Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. boasts an international membership exceeding 350,000 women of distinction, with more than 275 members belonging to the Pittsburgh Alumnae Chapter. These members have made notable contributions to civic life, education, health equity, and social impact in Pittsburgh, serving across sectors while exemplifying the highest standards of public service and community uplift;

 

NOW, THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the Council of the City of Pittsburgh does hereby declare April 1, 2025 to be “Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Day” in the City of Pittsburgh.

WHEREAS, Dr. Shamika Zyhier is a professor of nursing at Robert Morris University with 20 years of experience in the clinical field. She comes with diverse experience in the nursing field as a critical care clinician specializing in cardiovascular, thoracic, and open-heart transplant surgery patient care; and, 

 

body

WHEREAS, before beginning her nursing career, Dr. Zyhier worked as an accounting associate at the United Negro College Fund in New York City. Upon relocating to Pittsburgh, she transitioned into the tech industry, holding roles as a software programmer, systems analyst, and database administrator. She later served as director of operations for an underground line locating company, overseeing services across Pennsylvania, West Virginia, New York, New Jersey, Texas, South Dakota, and Missouri for 18 years; and, 

 

WHEREAS, she earned two undergraduate degrees before pursuing nursing-one in accounting from the City University of New York and another in software programming from the Community College of Allegheny County. Following the events of September 11, 2001, she returned to school and obtained her nursing diploma from the West Penn Hospital School of Nursing; and,

 

WHEREAS, she went on to earn her Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) from Clarion University, followed by a Master of Science in Nursing (MSN) with a focus in Education from Robert Morris University. She later completed her Ph.D. in Instructional Management and Leadership, also at Robert Morris University; and,

 

WHEREAS, Shamika aligns her learning and mentoring with the work of Marion Wright Edelman which encourages us to use, “education for improving the lives of others and leaving your community and world better than you found it”; and,

 

WHEREAS, she celebrates her life with Sharif Allah Zyhier, her husband of 50 years, and their 7 children, 16 grandchildren, and 3 great grandchildren; and,

 

NOW, THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the Council of the City of Pittsburgh does hereby recognize Shamika Zyhier and commend her for her dedicated service in helping others; and,

 

BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Council of the City of Pittsburgh does hereby declare Wednesday, April 2, 2025 to be “Shamika Zyhier Day” in the City of Pittsburgh.

body

Be it resolved by the Council of the City of Pittsburgh as follows:

 

Section 1.                     Resolution No. 564 of 2024, entitled “Resolution authorizing thirty-six (36) Open-End Professional Services Agreements with multiple vendors to provide professional services on an on-call basis as required related to various professional services as needed by the various Departments of the City of Pittsburgh, each Agreement being at an amount not-to-exceed one million five hundred thousand dollars ($1,500,000) annually for a three-year term, and providing for funding of the costs thereof” is hereby amended as follows:

 

SECTION 1. The City of Pittsburgh, through the Office of Management & Budget, is hereby authorized to enter into ninety two (92) Open-End Professional Services Agreements with multiple vendors for three (3) year terms, in order to provide professional services on an on-call basis as required related to various professional services as needed by the various Departments of the City of Pittsburgh.

 

SECTION 2. Because the agreements provide services on an as-needed basis, expenditures under these agreements will be identified when work orders are issued. If funding for any work order has not been previously appropriated, funding will be identified and appropriated through subsequent City Council action.  Funding is available as appropriated when listed per project in the Operating and/or Capital Budget.  

 

SECTION 3. No agreement will cost an amount greater than one million five hundred thousand dollars ($1,500,000) per year. In no event will any estimated work order for a project issued under these agreements exceed five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) in value.

Resolution authorizing the Mayor and the Director of the Department of Public Works, and/or the Director of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure, on behalf of the City of Pittsburgh, to enter into a cooperation agreement with the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership, providing for assignment of ownership and maintenance of certain infrastructure to be constructed by the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership, for the improvement of Market Square, at no cost to the City.  

 

Body

WHEREAS, the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership (“PDP”) is preparing to undertake a multi-million-dollar construction improvement project to Market Square located in the City of Pittsburgh (the “Project”); and

 

WHEREAS, the Project will improve and construct public infrastructure in Market Square as part of a general revitalization effort for the Downtown Pittsburgh neighborhood; and 

 

WHEREAS, the City of Pittsburgh and PDP wish to cooperate on dedication of certain infrastructure to the City as well as division of certain maintenance responsibilities; and

 

WHEREAS, both the City of Pittsburgh and PDP wish to enter into a cooperation agreement in order to memorialize respective responsibilities toward the Project.

 

Be it resolved by the Council of the City of Pittsburgh as follows:

 

Section 1.                     The Mayor and the Director of the Department of Public Works, and/or the Director of the Department of Mobility and Infrastructure, on behalf of the City of Pittsburgh, are authorized to enter into a cooperation agreement or agreements with the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership, providing for assignment of ownership and maintenance of certain infrastructure to be constructed by the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership, for the improvement of Market Square, at no cost to the City.

 

SECTION 2. The Agreement and Amendments thereto shall be approved by the City Solicitor as to form.
